title: 108_s337
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arsenic-Treated Residential-Use Wood Prohibition Act" and includes hazardous waste classification. The Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to include regulations on CCA-treated wood, defining arsenic-treated wood and CCA-treated wood as wood treated with specific pesticides. Regulation of CCA-treated wood requires disposal in a lined landfill with a leachate system to prevent arsenic contamination of groundwater. The Administrator, in consultation with the Consumer Products Safety Commission, will publish a risk assessment of CCA-treated wood by March 15, 2003, following recommended methodology by Scientific Advisory Panels. The United States Environmental Protection Agency organized panels in October 2001 to address the prohibition of production of CCA-treated wood. Regulations were to be promulgated for the cessation of production within 60 days of enactment and to prohibit production thereafter. The United States Environmental Protection Agency organized panels in October 2001 to address the prohibition of production of CCA-treated wood. If the Administrator publishes a notice in the Federal Register declaring certain uses of CCA-treated wood as safe, exemptions will be granted for railroad ties, marine pilings, and utility poles. The Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act is amended to prohibit certain uses of arsenic-treated lumber. The Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act is amended to prohibit the use of CCA-treated wood, which is wood treated with a chromated copper arsenical pesticide. Manufacturing of CCA-treated wood products for consumer assembly or according to consumer specifications is included in the prohibition. Regulations must be enacted within 90 days of the subsection's enactment. The Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act is amended to prohibit the use of CCA-treated wood in products for children and residential or occupational purposes. Regulations must be enacted within 90 days of the subsection's enactment. The Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act is amended to remove sections 30 and 31 and replace them with new items. The Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act is amended to include new sections on training requirements for maintenance applicators and service technicians, minor use programs by the EPA and Department of Agriculture, prohibition of certain uses of arsenic-treated lumber, severability, and authorization for appropriations. Assistance is provided to consumers, state and local governments, and school systems. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will develop an educational program within 180 days to assist in testing arsenic levels in CCA-treated wood and soil, and making containment decisions. The Administrator will establish a pilot program to assist school systems in removing CCA-treated wood from playgrounds, applying sealant to structures, and conducting necessary remediation. Authorization of Appropriations.--Such sums as necessary are authorized for carrying out this section, including remediation related to CCA-treated wood use.
